The program as implemented below benefits the fact that if the state = 0 (after the seed time until the end of the period the outputs (NewMemVal ; NewSate ; Direction) is (0;0;0)."}},"574":{"type":"Notes","name":"Hello World","x":25,"y":40,"ins":[],"inNames":[],"outNames":[],"params":{"text":"2 state & 8 bit Turing Machine
------------------------------

Here I do realize an old dream in noisecraft : to craft a simple Turing Machine! It cost me a lot of energy until the solution appeared.

A Turing machine is a computer conceptualized by Alan Turing (1912-1954) : an infinite memory tape on which at least two symbols can be read and written by a moving head following a program of the form : 

If the head is in the State 1 and reads the symbol 1, then it has to replace it by the symbol 0, go to the right and put itself in the state 2. All calculable functions can be calculated by this elementary computing process and every program in the world can be reduced to a Turing machine.

In my implementation, the tape is only 8 bits long (8 places with zeros or ones) and the program is defined only for 2 states (1 and 2). If the Head is at the end of the tape on the right (position 8) and has to move to the right, then it shifts to left of the tape (position 1). The same thing happens from the extreme left of the tape to the extreme right.

My implementation first fills the 8 bit memory with random bits (0 or 1), then applies the program.

I had to handle with unwanted but necessary delays due to the fact that the Hold (memory) node triggers on the rising edge of a pulse (when it crosses 0 from -1 to +1). this happens after a 1/2 period delay (see Random bits Note).

I wrote a lot of Notes to explain the different parts of the craft. I hope it will help.

What to do with it ?

The Memory (MEM) could be used to code frequencies, or other modulation values, or trigger some event. The same can be done with (NewMemVal>)

NewState, Direction and NewHeadPosition, can also be used for some kind of modulation.

So Enjoy, 

(a or not b)
